2.author: Zphr
2.body:
You might have noted that there is a surge in frugal deals/finds/hauls on Fridays now.  This is because of a new sub policy we're trialing called Frugal Finds Fridays.  Basically, such posts are fine to put up as separate independent posts on Fridays, but on all other days they get removed unless the OP wants to post them as a comment in the monthly megathread.  Most folks prefer to hold their wins for the following Friday, hence the surge.

We're trying to find a happy medium where hauls/finds don't persistently clog up the sub, which we know bothers many folks, while still leaving people the opportunity to celebrate their awesome frugal wins.

Everyone should certainly feel free to report hauls/finds posted outside of Fridays for us to review.

2.author: RelayFX
2.body:
We recently instituted our beta of Frugal Finds Friday to give people a chance just to show off things they found. We don’t allow these “deals” or other “finds” posts at any other time of the week unless it provides something that’s pretty universally beneficial/replicable. 

It’s a delicate balance between the “quality” content and these sorts of “celebratory haul” posts. Both types of content serve different purposes and ultimately, people like sharing their achievements. We’re experimenting with this “blend” of content to try to find a happy medium that works for everyone (or at least as many people as possible).

We do have the megathread, but that’s only useful to certain circumstances/cases and users can’t post images of their hauls because Reddit won’t let us turn on images in comments for only one thread.

It’s a work in progress/not “final”, so feedback is certainly welcome!

10.author: kingofallnorway
10.body:
This is really interesting. Could you share your tips on how to refill cartridges, i.e. what I'll need, and either video or written guides? By any chance are your cartridges PG-243, 245, or 245XL? Those are the kinds I need to refill.

I'm a bit intimidated but it's 100% worth it to me because of the savings. I'm a DIY type of person

10.author: LazyFridge
10.body:
There are a lot of videos on YouTube, just search for “<cartridge name> refill”
I recently refilled PG 275 and PG 276, they are pretty similar to yours. Printer still signals that ink is low but prints perfectly. Hope there is no “intellect” that disables the cartridge after some time.

For these models printing head is integrated into the cartridge. So it the head is damaged or worn out just throw the cartridge away and get a new one.

10.author: kingofallnorway
10.body:
What method works best for you? A lot of these guides have different approaches, I just want a simple way that I can repeat easily. 

When you refill, does it seal correctly? I've heard that if you don't seal it right the ink will just dry up. I'm curious how many pages of prints I can get when refilling

10.author: LazyFridge
10.body:
I did this https://youtu.be/NUOrtHGbb1o
The top cover must be attached with a tape. Looks a little ugly, but I have no concern about ink drying up

There is another approach where you need to drill a hole in the cover then inject ink with a syringe. There will be no need to attach the cover back, but you cannot see how full the cartridge is. Also a few particles can get inside the cartridge during drilling.

10.author: LazyFridge
10.body: I have no statistic on this cartridge yet

11.author: RafiqTheHero
11.body:
I would definitely suggest looking up some of the cards on TCGPlayer for gaming cards.

If some are Magic the Gathering cards, the rarity symbol is an ok indicator of the card's value. Most of the highly valuable cards will be rare (gold symbol on the middle of the right near the card type) or mythic rare (orangeish/purplish color). Those would be most worth your time looking up individually to determine value.

11.author: RafiqTheHero
11.body:
>A good card in bad shape isn’t worth much.

That's actually not true, at least for collectible card games like Magic the Gathering. Yes, a card in poor shape will be worth less, but if the card in good condition were worth $100, the card in bad condition might still be worth $50.

11.author: Secret_Ad_5300
11.body:
Yeh I understand, your not wrong, but if we’re talking 1000s of cards, quickest way to sort first is ignoring bad shaped ones, once I got through those I would then move onto the worse ones.

But the real value in a card is also getting it graded. Not really worth the time and effort if it’s a 5 PSA

23.author: Heytherestairs
23.body: Petite is supposed to be for anyone under 5’3-5’4. Although a lot of department store petite sections are geared more towards middle aged women because that’s their consumer base. Vanity sizing is also a problem. So on top of short/petite inseams being way too long for people who are short, it also excludes the ones who might need smaller measurements in general. It’s not easy for a lot of people to just go into a store/online and just find something that fits perfectly off the rack.

23.author: Heytherestairs
23.body: Nope. It’s funny that you think sizing is only a local problem. I mostly online shop. It’s a widespread problem. If I can’t even find it online, then finding it in person would be close to impossible.

23.author: Pushing59
23.body: I meant that I could find ladies pants in lengths in our area.

23.author: Heytherestairs
23.body: You missed the point that different lengths in women’s isn’t standardized like it is in men’s sizing where it’s waist by length. It’s an arbitrary sizing label short, regular, and tall which can vary in actual inseam length by brand. So while you may see different labels, the actual lengths may not fit every person. So it’s much easier said than done to just go out and buy the right length. It’s not always possible and it’s not good advice to give to someone.

23.author: Pushing59

See I take commissions from coworkers but I don’t charge as much as my husband thinks I should (or as much as a lot of other crafters think a person should charge) but I do it for fun and because I love it and most of my coworkers aren’t rich, they’re lower middle class at best and I don’t think that should be a reason not to be able to order a handmade item. Besides I know where they work lol. 

This year though I’m making it a priority to try and make things for myself a bit more. I keep making stuff for other people and putting things I want for myself to the side. But since focusing more on my creative aspects I’ve been much happier.

31.author: Nmcoyote1
31.body: I have to do this because there is no wired option at my home. I use Visible $25 legacy plan on my phone and a grandfathered $65 Verizon pUDP Jetpack plan. These options work fine most of the time. But wireless options are never as great as a decent wired/fiber option. Using Visible as home internet will degrade your phone battery faster. I use Visible as backup and my phone plan. The Jetpack has been on 24/7 as my home internet for 3+ years.  I have to replace the battery in it about once per year and reboot it several times per week. I find using my phone as home internet is more problematic then the Jetpack, but they both work. If I had my choice, I would have wired internet. The big problem is finding an unlimited plan with unlimited hotspot. Visible is probably the best phone option because of unlimited 5 MBPS hotspot.

My idea is to have internet on my phone and when I get home to use it for my TV and laptop.

I am worried about an untold limit for sure, all mobile companies here are horrible. Right now I have no limit on calls (excluding payed numbers of course) and I noticed that pretty often the connection will get lost at exactly 15:03 minutes of the call.

44.author: FavoriteScreamer

57.author: idiocracyI
57.body:
>I believe

That's probably the keyword here. Sorry, but statistics generally tell otherwise.

But maybe I am not getting it. How are roundabouts built in MA?

57.author: empirerec8
57.body:
I'm not sure what you are getting at with the whole statics thing. 

I mean the city redesigned the rotary to make it safer/less accidents (that's my understanding at least).  They must have had statistics to support it or they wouldn't have wasted their money to redo it.

Before it had lights and was wide enough for more than one car to go around it (but no defined lanes and more cars to merge with when entering/ exiting).  Now it is designed so that one car enters when there is a free spot to enter (not determined at all by any lights) and it's one lane all the way around.  Supposedly this is supposed to help with less traffic and less accidents.

57.author: idiocracyI
57.body:
>Now it is designed so that one car enters when there is a free spot to ent

Exactly, roundabouts don't have lights. You usually have one lane and two lane roundabouts. In big cities there are often multilane roundabouts as well.

57.author: empirerec8
57.body:
I mean you can't really make a blanket statement that they don't have lights...because here they do have lights.  

We have another one in a city about 45 mins away from me... they re-designed that one to have a designated 3 or 4 lanes and lights to make that one safer in that area.  Before that it was huge and cars whipped around it.   Personally, I hate the lanes and lights now because I don't normally drive around there and I never remember which lane the highway is so I end up going around twice cuz I can't always switch lanes in time if there are lots of other cars but for the people that normally drive there maybe it is now better for them because the lights make it so you can't go so fast. 🤷‍♀️

57.author: idiocracyI
57.body:
OK, if I understand you correctly, they converted your regular two lane roundabout into a signaled one lane roundabout. Sounds like a local traffic engineering measure to help the confused drivers to adapt to roundabouts. Signaled roundabouts with entry control usually only pop up in the context of controlling heavy traffic flow e.g. multi-lane interstate traffic.

You make a good point, though. Roundabouts are not well liked and even feared in the US. Their initial introduction was actually a complete failure. And that's one of the reasons why we still have to wait for like 3 min at each of the 10 traffic lights on our way to work instead of just breezing through in half the time and with less accidents :-)

59.author: Ylurpn
59.body:
Since biltong takes a few days to cook regardless, temperature isn't really monitored, instead, airflow is the more important part of it. If you were to use more than 40 watts, you might need to monitor it to make sure you aren't overcooking, but really, the 40 watt bulb just speeds it up a bit. 

I'm certainly no expert though, if you search "biltong box" on YouTube, there are a lot of good videos that tell you how to make the box, what cuts of beef to get, and how to season it. 

You can play with a lot of factors except for these 3:
- you must cure the meat in vinegar for atleast 30 minutes
- you must season the meat with corriander seed
- you must not let the beef sit against the walls of your biltong box

These 3 things are imperative to killing bacteria on the meats and making it all safe to eat. You can get by without doing these 3 things, but you dramatically increase the risk

64.author: whitefire89
64.body: That will depend on a number of factors.  There is no universal answer.

64.author: wtf_is_this_news
64.body: Yeah that’s why I was challenging that advice. It’s complicated and I’m curious how the factors affect the answer

64.author: wtf_is_this_news
64.body: Yeah people keep explaining it and I keep asking how they know it to be true and they do not know. How long would you need to keep the ice in there to be worth it? 1 day? 1 year? If you do not know that answer, how do you know it’s a good idea?

64.author: whitefire89
64.body:
I am not sure about what is hard to figure out about it.  The warmer any air can get in there, be it the seal, the insulation,  opening the door, how much space is air, etc., the more the frozen jugs will help.  Air dissipates easily,  which decreases efficiency.  Having frozen jugs, increases it.  

Now, if the freezer works for two days to freeze them, it will need some time to make up the difference.  After that, it is a net win.

64.author: wtf_is_this_news
64.body: Yeah my question is how many days does it take for net win? Is it days, weeks, months, years? How did you figure that out?

64.author: whitefire89
64.body: You should have to do an independent study on each individual situation to figure that out.

64.author: wtf_is_this_news
64.body: Yeah that might be the way to go about it. Though I wonder why people are so confident about the water jug thing if they haven’t done this or read about something doing this.

64.author: whitefire89
64.body:
Theoretically it makes sense.  Go an
Head and run a test.  The equipment is out there.  The more you open the door, or the less efficient the freezer is, the bigger difference you will sew.  I even worked for an appliance company, and efficiency tests were done.  Keeping it full, with cold items, was definitely recommended.

64.author: wtf_is_this_news
64.body: Yeah I get that full is better than half full. Again, the latent heat adds an extra energy cost up front and the pay off is questionable. I don’t think I’ll run any tests on this though. We’re talking about saving a dollar per year.

70.author: SereneDreams03

Well, there you go, we read different sources. I mostly read NPR, my local paper, and sometimes articles that pop up on my reddit feed. And those sources have mostly just been covering conservative reaction to the issue. I could care less what your personal political affiliation is.

>If I had to convert my house to electric I wouldn't be able to afford to heat it.

Really, Just curious what the price difference would be? 

My state has one of the cheapest energy rates in the country, so that is why I said that when the time comes to replace my appliances, I'll be switching to electric. Once again, I'm not saying everyone has to convert right now and that it is the greatest threat to our health, just that it is a consideration.

70.author: Mr_Fraunces
70.body: My house is about 125 years old and runs a steam boiler off of natural gas, converted from coal. They don't even make residential electric steam boilers. The majority of electricity in the US is generated by natural gas, if natural gas is so bad for people I would feel bad for all of the people who live in the vicinity of electrical generating plants if I didn't share the risks. It would be hypocritical of me to switch to electric because of the dangers of natural gas while expecting people who live near gas fired plants to take on more risk.

70.author: SereneDreams03
70.body:
Interesting, yeah, I don't think the typical American lives in a 125 year old home running off a steam boiler, but I can definitely understand why it wouldn't be worthwhile to you moving over to electric.

Most of the energy in my state is renewable. Only about 12% comes from natural gas. So, in my case, at least transferring my home solely to the electrical grid wouldn't really be harming my neighbors. Even in the states that do run off more natural gas though, having a power plant in a nearby location is a little different than having gas burning appliances in your home, the risks are not exactly the same.

72.author: Napalmdeathfromabove
72.body:
Scotch bonnet and , out of shot, the bhut joloki I managed to grow. Only a half dozen small ones of those.


As for how long will it last?  It's in vinegar essentially so as long as I keep it out of the sunlight I'm going to guess a year at least as that's how long the pickles I've made last .

How I made it


Finely chopped up red onion, fried slowly in a little salt .

Added the chopped up chili

Cooked it all for a little while to soften it up

Added white wine vinager, simmered it all for a bit.

Added tablespoon of brown soft suger


Turned it off to cool, blitzed it in magic bullet type thing.

Decanted when not so hot it burned.
